titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Finding aid prepared by Anne Harney

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T19:48-0400

did.abstract: This collection contains the diaries, journals, and observations of a naturalist, generously illustrated with newspaper clippings, photographs, letters, sketches, maps, and charts. This collection contains primarily correspondence, but includes articles and addresses by Murphy as well as scrapbooks, photographs, and other miscellaneous volumes documenting his career. From his earliest travels to South American and the Antarctic regions in 1912, until his Australia voyage in 1971, Murphy continually explored animal and bird life as a scientist, and also as a concerned citizen who became one of the earliest advocates of conservation and ecology.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Presented by Robert Cushman Murphy, 1967-1970; Mrs. Grace E. B. Murphy, 1973, 1975; #42 journal presented by Mrs. Alison Murphy Conner, 1979 and accessioned, 1984 (1984 607ms). See in-house shelf list for additional accession numbers and dates.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Robert Cushman Murphy (1887-1973), one of the twentieth century’s great ornithologists, was curator of mammals and birds at the Brooklyn Museum (1911-1917) and was curator of birds and later chairman of birds at the American Museum of Natural History (1917-1973). The world’s foremost authority on sea birds, in 1936, he penned Oceanic Birds of South America, a two volume set. An ardent traveler and explorer, he kept copious notes of his travels, which he typed up, illustrated and had bound. The APS library owns forty-two bound journals. Murphy was made an APS member in 1946. A pioneer in the study of the ecology, a louse, fish, plant, lizard, an Antarctic inlet, spider, and two mountains have acquired his name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Native American Images note : Seventy Native American black & white silver gelatin photographs, sketches, maps and prints by Robert Cushman Murphy from 1900-1965. Taken or drawn during his natural history expeditions to Baja California, Florida, Panama, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru, the images represent native portraits, encampments, dress and weapons. Tribes covered include Choco, Cocopa, Seminole, and Quechua. Also, includes images of the Montauk of Long Island, N.Y. Of particular interest, a sketch of Huaco pottery and watercolors of Quechua Indians. Note: the images are in the journals entitled Baja California, 1915; Florida Fisheries, 1919; Peruvian Littoral Expedition, 1919-1920; Expedition to Peru and Ecuador, 1924-1925; Choco Expedition, 1937; Long Island and Elsewhere, 1900, 1964-1965. Also referenced in Freeman’s Guide to Manuscripts relating to the American Indian and its Supplement and Murphy Smith’s Historical American Sketches.

did.unittitle: Bay of Pisco and waters about Paracas Peninsula
Santa Rosita Island and Isla Viegas
13. Peru, 1953-1954. Oceanography, fish, birds, fishing operations, guano
Coastal valley north of Lima, Peru

15. Askoy Expedition, 1941. Voyage in the schooner Askoy along the coasts of Darien, Colombia, and Ecuador to the Malpelo Islands, investigating shorelines and outlying pelagic waters from points of view of geographer, oceanographer, and marine biologist
16. New Zealand, 1947-1948. New Zealand flora, fauna, and sea-life; Seventh Pacific Science Congress
R. C. Murphy's New Zealand travel route
17. New Zealand, 1949. New Zealand flora, fauna, and sea-life; Seventh Pacific Science Congress
Mauna Loa, Hawaii, and Island of Hawaii
18. Low Country, 1928-1947. South Carolina and southeastern United States
19. Bermuda, 1951. Rediscovery of the cahow, or Bermuda petrel
20. Coast to Coast, and Mexico, 1955-1956. A 12,000-mile motor trip to British Columbia, the west coast of the United States, and Mexico
21. Around the World, 1957-1958. Ninth Pacific Science Congress
22. Operation Deep Freeze, 1960. Cruise of the U.S.S. Glacier in Antarctica, to the head of the Bellingshausen Sea
23. South Georgia Expedition, 1912-1913. Microfilm. Printed as Logbook for Grace. See volume 30 below
24. Venezuela, 1952. Birds and fish of the coastal areas
26. Europe, 1950. Congressus Internationalis Ornithologicus, at Uppsala
27. Stranger Pacific Cruise, 1956. Journal of the Scripps Cooperative Oceanic Productivity Expedition
28. San José Island, 1945. Flora and fauna of an island "which has had almost no human inhabitants since the extermination of the native Indians early in the 16th century"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Native American images note: 2 watercolor sketches, 1 ink sketch.

did.unittitle: 38. Chocó Expedition, 1937. Field work in the launch "Wilpet" between Panama and Ecuador

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Primarily concerned with collection of water samples from the Pacific, meteorological data, etc. Some notes and discussion of Indians of Colombia and Ecuador. Groups mentioned: Choco, Citara, Noanama, Cholo, Paparo, Tucura, and Cuna. Native American images note: 2 photomechanical prints, 2 black and white silver gelatin prints.

did.unittitle: Map of Panama and Colombia Indian tribes
41. The Way of the Sperm Whale, 1912-1913. Photo essay on whale hunting and way of life, while aboard the brig Daisy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Diary of Robert Cushman Murphy, includes many illustrations, sketches, and photographs pertaining to his early life. Native American images note: 23 pencil and ink sketches of arrowheads found near boyhood home, portraits of Sioux.
